awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Influence of Ionic Liquids on Product Selectivity in CO2 Electroreduction over Copper Catalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
Carbon dioxide (CO2) electroreduction holds promise for producing fuels and chemicals from waste CO2 and renewable electricity. Opportunities exist to produce more high order hydrocarbons and alcohols, however controlling product selectivity and having high activity remain as the key challenges to overcome. The proposed exploratory research project aims to investigate the use of copper (Cu) and ionic liquids (ILs) as co-catalysts for the conversion of CO2 to valuable chemicals and fuels. This is a high risk-high payoff project that may lead to the development of technologies for on-demand conversion of CO2 to fuels and chemicals using renewable electricity.

Breakthroughs in achieving high product selectivity for hydrocarbons and alcohols are possible by using ILs as dilute aqueous additives in CO2 electroreduction over Cu. The central hypothesis of the proposed EAGER project is that the utilization of ILs as co-catalysts at low concentrations in aqueous electrolytes can suppress the hydrogen evolution reaction and enhance CO2 electroreduction selectivity towards higher order hydrocarbons and alcohols on Cu catalysts. By modifying the IL cation-anion pair, the thermophysical and chemical properties of the IL can be altered dramatically. The proposed research plan seeks to identify the key properties an IL must have in order to be a good co-catalyst for the enhancement of the faradaic efficiency towards hydrocarbons and alcohols. To test the hypothesis, the work is split into two main objectives: 1) Identify key IL structure properties that influence faradaic efficiency of CO2t electroreduction, and 2) Determine if there are synergistic effects between IL and Cu morphology on CO2 electroreduction faradaic efficiency. The scientific insights developed for selecting ILs based upon their structure-property relationships will be transferable to other electrochemical systems, significantly impacting the way ILs are used. The proposed research plan may also be applicable to other electrochemical synthesis methods, such as electrochemical ammonia synthesis and electrochemical hydrogenations, and other electrochemical systems, such as batteries, fuel cells and waste treatment. The educational broader impacts of the proposal include scientific workforce development, particularly of women in STEM fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on using ionic liquids (ILs) as electrolytes in CO2 electroreduction (CO2RR) to modify and control product selectivity over copper catalysts. While copper catalysts allow for a variety of valuable products to be produced that cannot be formed on other catalysts, achieving high selectivity towards any given product remains a challenge. Additionally, the relationship between IL structure and its impact on product selectivity in CO2 electroreduction is not well understood. In this project, we used ionic liquids as a modifier in the electrolyte, rather than a complete electrolyte replacement. This was to minimize mass transfer limitations due to high viscosities of the ionic liquids and allow for hydrocarbons to be produced, which require a proton or water source.

Both the influence of the cation and anion were investigated with 10 mM concentrations of salt additives in 0.1M KHCO3 electrolytes. Using a series of ILs with the same cation (1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium ([BMIM]+)) and various anions: bis(trifuoromethylsulfonyl)imide ([NTF2]− ), trifate ([OTF]− ), acetate ([Ac]− ), chloride([Cl]− ), and dicyanamide ([DCA]−), we investigated the influence of the anion. The type of anion was found to have a significant impact on product selectivity. In particular, the [NTF2]- -containing electrolytes promoted formate formation, while the [DCA]—containing electrolytes suppressed CO2 electroreduction and promoted the competing hydrogen evolution reaction. Further investigation of the [NTF2]- and [DCA]- results were made replacing the [BMIM]+ cation with K+ or Na+. While there were small differences when the [BMIM]+ was replaced, the overall observations that the anion had the stronger influence on product selectivity held.

The products were analyzed through bulk electrolysis experiments and the electrode interface was studied through spectroscopic and modeling methods to identify why the anion had a such strong influence on product selectivity. The hydrophobic/hydrophilic nature of the anion and propensity to adsorb to the electrode surface appeared to play a significant role in the reaction selectivity. The [NTF2]- anion is hydrophobic, helping to keep water away from the electrode surface and CO2 close to the surface. The [DCA]-­ anion is hydrophilic, helping keep water close to the surface and CO2 away from the surface. [DCA]- also strongly adsorbs to the copper electrode.

Intellectual Merit

Developing a clear understanding on the factors that control product selectivity to higher order products and improve activity in CO2 electroreduction is necessary to enable breakthroughs in the technology. As a result of this work, the scientific insights developed for selecting ILs based upon their structure-property relationships will transferable to other electrochemical systems, significantly impacting the way ILs are used. The findings have direct implications for electrochemical synthesis methods including CO2 electroreduction, electrochemical ammonia synthesis and electrochemical hydrogenations and also be applicable to other electrochemical systems such as batteries, fuel cells and waste treatment.

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of the work include being able to reduce CO2 to valuable chemicals and fuels on-demand using renewable electricity that could reduce transportation and storage costs and risks, reduce CO2 emissions, and utilize renewable electricity. Improving electrochemical devices to be more energy efficient can make them more viable options for storing and converting energy, cleaning wastewater, and making chemicals. These improvements can also make electrochemical devices beyond batteries an option for managing the renewable electricity grid. The educational broader impacts include scientific workforce development, particularly of women in STEM.
